title: Gunman Fatally Shoots Officer and 3 Others in Midtown Office Tower
summary: The gunman, armed with an assault rifle, walked into the lobby and killed a police officer and two others. He killed another person on the 33rd floor before turning his gun on himself.

title: A Shooting in New York Skyscraper, and Harvard’s Potential $500 Million Deal
summary: Plus, when the peanut M&M was in trouble.

title: Trump Is Winning His Trade War. What Will That Mean for the Economy?
summary: The president’s vision for reshaping global trade is falling into place, but he is embarking on an experiment that economists say could still produce damaging results.

title: Europe Made Major Trade Concessions to Trump. How Did That Happen?
summary: Some European politicians are dismayed that the European Union did not drive a harder bargain, but facing the threat of a damaging trade war, officials say they had little choice.

title: Trump’s Tariffs on Medicines From Europe Stand to Cost Drugmakers Billions
summary: Many pharmaceutical products made in Europe will face a 15 percent tariff, pinching manufacturers and potentially leading to higher drug prices.

title: Why It Matters That India and Trump Don’t Have a Tariff Deal
summary: The stakes are high, with the United States and India counting on one another as indispensable partners in their competition with China.

title: Harvard Is Said to Be Open to Spending Up to $500 Million to Resolve Trump Dispute
summary: The sum sought by the government is more than twice as much as the $200 million fine that Columbia University said it would pay when it settled its clash with the White House last week.

title: Vance Embraces Role of Loyal Trump Warrior, Shifting Away From Past Stances
summary: The vice president has defended the administration’s handling of U.S. military engagement abroad and the Epstein files, even when those positions put him at odds with the right wing.

title: Starmer Is Edging Closer to Recognizing a Palestinian State, UK Officials Say
summary: Two government officials said Britain was actively weighing the recognition of a Palestinian state, in a shift driven by public pressure over starvation in Gaza.

title: ‘Worst-Case Scenario of Famine’ Unfolding in Gaza, U.N.-Backed Body Says
summary: Access to food has plummeted to unprecedented levels, a monitoring group warned, as global outrage over Israel’s aid restrictions persisted.

title: For Trump, Starvation in Gaza Tests His Foreign Policy Approach
summary: President Trump will have to decide whether America intends to take a leading role in confronting one of the biggest humanitarian catastrophes of the 21st century.

title: Powell Under Siege as Fed Plans to Stand Pat on Rate Cuts
summary: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, is facing relentless attacks from the president, a lively campaign to replace him and divisions in his own ranks over when to cut interest rates.

title: Shoppers Embrace ‘Christmas in July’ Amid Rising Costs and Tariff Limbo
summary: People are starting their holiday shopping earlier this year, using summer sales from retailers like Amazon and Walmart to save time and money.

title: Study May Undercut Idea That Cash Payments to Poor Families Help Child Development
summary: Rigorous new research appears to show that monthly checks intended to help disadvantaged children did little for their well-being, adding a new element to a dispute over expanded government aid.

title: In Fight for House, New York May Follow Texas in Redrawing Maps
summary: Democrats in three states are now considering moves to counter a push by Texas Republicans to redraw their state’s maps.

title: N.J. Criminal Cases Screech to a Halt as Habba’s Authority Is Challenged
summary: Federal court hearings, grand jury proceedings and plea deals were abruptly canceled in New Jersey over questions about whether Alina Habba, the acting U.S. attorney, was legally appointed.

title: Paul Dans, Project 2025 Architect, Will Challenge Lindsey Graham for Senate
summary: Paul Dans will run in the South Carolina primary highlighting the work of Project 2025, a conservative blueprint that President Trump has employed during his second term.

title: Union Pacific to Buy Norfolk Southern in $85 Billion Railroad Deal
summary: The merger would create the United States’ first coast-to-coast rail network, spanning 50,000 miles and 43 states.

title: Ryne Sandberg, Hall of Fame Second Baseman for the Cubs, Dies at 65
summary: Both a skilled fielder and a fearsome power hitter, he entered the national sports spotlight with two memorable home runs in a nationally televised 1984 game.

title: Gwyneth Paltrow Is Astronomer’s ‘Temporary Spokesperson’ After Coldplay Kiss-Cam Scandal
summary: The technology company that was at the center of a scandal last week released a tongue-in-cheek response. It landed.

title: Trump, Juan Crow and Who Gets to Be an American
summary: The rights conferred to all by the Constitution are now subject to a sliding scale of extralegal violability depending on race, ethnicity or assumed immigration status.

title: Lina Khan: Democrats Can Learn from Zohran Mamdani
summary: Democrats Need to Win Back America’s Small Businesses

title: Your Questions About Education
summary: Our reporters address reader submissions.

title: Jimmy Fallon Ridicules Trump’s Choice Words About Epstein Island
summary: The president said he “never had the privilege” of visiting Jeffrey Epstein’s island. Fallon’s take: “Trump’s staff was like, ‘A simple no would’ve been fine.’ ”

title: Heavy Rain and Flooding in China Kill at Least 30
summary: The rains set off flooding and landslides, forcing tens of thousands of people to flee their homes in the capital and neighboring Hebei Province.

title: Russian Strike on Prison Kills 16, Ukraine Says
summary: The attack, which came just hours after President Trump gave the Kremlin a new deadline to work toward ending the war, was part of a wave across the country, the authorities said.

title: India Says It Killed 3 Militants Behind Spring Terrorist Attack in Kashmir
summary: The government has faced criticism for being slow to catch the shooters who slaughtered 26 civilians and started clashes between India and Pakistan.

title: Finland’s Short, Precious Summers Are Plagued by Goose Poop
summary: Finns trying to enjoy beaches and parks during their all-too-brief summers have been vexed by legions of geese — and their droppings. The smelly mess has resisted even the most innovative solutions.
